In 1990, Aeritalia and Selenia were merged by parent company [[Finmeccanica]]{{Cite web|title = Storia - Finmeccanica|url = http://www.finmeccanica.com/en/one-company/storia1_history1?WT.ac=Storia|website = www.finmeccanica.com|access-date = 2016-02-14}} as [[Alenia Aeronautica]]. ==History== Aerfer and Fiat merged their aircraft businesses in 1969 to create Aeritalia. The concentration led to milestone programs such as the European attack aircraft Tornado, the ATR family, and the AMX. Aeritalia was also a partner in the Boeing 767 from its inception, and played a key role in the creation of the Italian space industry. In 1990, Aeritalia merged with [[Selenia (company)|Selenia]] to form [[Alenia Aeronautica]], the aerospace arm of [[Finmeccanica]]. ==Aircraft== * [[Aeritalia F-104S]] * [[AMX International AMX]] * [[ATR-42]] * [[Aeritalia G.91]] * [[Aeritalia G.91Y]] * [[Aeritalia G.222]] ==Rockets== * [[Alfa (rocket)]] ==See also== {{Portal|Italy|Companies|Aviation}} * [[List of Italian companies#Aircraft companies|List of Italian companies]] ==References== {{Reflist}} == External links == {{commons category|position=left|Aeritalia}} {{Aeritalia aircraft}} {{Leonardo-Finmeccanica}} [[Category:1969 establishments in Italy]] [[Category:1990 disestablishments in Italy]] [[Category:Technology companies established in 1969]] [[Category:Technology companies disestablished in 1990]] [[Category:Aeritalia| ]] [[Category:Alenia Aeronautica]] [[Category:Defunct aircraft manufacturers of Italy]] [[Category:Italian brands]] {{Aero-corp-stub}}

(2007)]] '''Air Nigeria''' (originally '''Virgin Nigeria Airways''', and then '''Nigerian Eagle Airlines'''), was the national [[flag carrier]] of [[Nigeria]],"[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-19545453 Air Nigeria ends international flights]." Retrieved on 11 December 2012. which operated scheduled regional and domestic passenger services. The airline's base was [[Murtala Mohammed International Airport]] in [[Ikeja]], its head office was in [[Lagos Island]], [[Lagos]] and the C&M building in Crawley,"[http://www.myairnigeria.com/en/ng/CONTACTUS/RegisteredOffice/tabid/204/language/en-US/Default.aspx Registered Office] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120518011700/http://www.myairnigeria.com/en/ng/CONTACTUS/RegisteredOffice/tabid/204/language/en-US/Default.aspx |date=2012-05-18 }}." Air Nigeria. Retrieved on 21 May 2012. "159/161 [[Broad Street, Lagos|Broad Street]], Marina Lagos Island Lagos, Nigeria." and its registered office was in [[Ikoyi]], Lagos."[https://web.archive.org/web/20100109084639/http://www.virginnigeria.com/en/ng/contact_ho.html AN Registered Offices]." Air Nigeria. Retrieved on 28 June 2010. "Registered Office 188 Awolowo Road South West Ikoyi Lagos, Nigeria. Head Office 9th Floor Etiebets Place 21, Mobolaji Bank-Anthony Way Ikeja Lagos, Nigeria. " The airline, which effectively replaced the defunct [[Nigeria Airways]], was founded in 2004 as a joint venture between Nigerian investors and the [[Virgin Group]]. Virgin withdrew from the business during 2008-2010. Following two name changes, Air Nigeria announced on 6 September 2012 that it had made its staff redundant and ceased operations on 10 September 2012.{{cite web|last=Brock|first=Joe|title=Air Nigeria shuts down in latest aviation setback|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/09/10/uk-nigeria-aviation-idUSLNE88901M20120910|publisher=Reuters|accessdate=10 September 2012}} == History == === Origins === On 28 September 2004, the Nigerian government and [[Virgin Group]] signed an agreement to establish a new airline for Nigeria, to be called '''Virgin Nigeria Airways'''. Nigerian institutional investors owned 51% of the company and [[Virgin Atlantic Airways]] the remaining 49%. The airline's inaugural flight was on 28 June 2005 from Lagos to [[London Heathrow Airport|London Heathrow]], using an [[Airbus A340]]-300 aircraft. Virgin Nigeria quickly became one of Nigeria's largest airlines, carrying its 1,000,000th passenger and 4,000th ton of freight within two years of operation. The airline has also received accolades including [[Thisday|THISDAY Awards]] 2006 Airline of the year[http://allafrica.com/stories/200703260311.html Virgin Nigeria wins 2006 Airline of the Year award.], AllAfrica.com website, retrieved March 27, 2007 and a nomination for 2006 African Airline of the year by ASATA (Association of South African Travel Agents).[http://www.asata.co.za/index.asp Virgin Nigeria nominated for 2006 African Airline of the year] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070216065030/http://www.asata.co.za/index.asp |date=2007-02-16 }}, Association of South African Travel Agents website, retrieved 27 March 2007 Virgin Nigeria had plans to make [[Nnamdi Azikiwe International Airport]] in Abuja its second base, where, in addition to its Lagos base [[Murtala Muhammed International Airport]], it would serve all countries in West Africa.[http://www.ainonline.com/news/single-news-page/article/virgin-nigeria-buys-bevy-of-embraer-regional-jets/?no_cache=1&cHash=221b1f7da9 Virgin Nigeria buys bevy of Embraer regional jets: AINonline] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071227095316/http://www.ainonline.com/news/single-news-page/article/virgin-nigeria-buys-bevy-of-embraer-regional-jets/?no_cache=1&cHash=221b1f7da9 |date=2007-12-27 }} The Nigerian government set a deadline of 30 April 2007 for all airlines operating in the country to re-capitalise or be grounded, in an effort to ensure better services and safety. The airline satisfied the [[Nigerian Civil Aviation Authority]] (NCAA)’s criteria in terms of re-capitalization and was re-registered for operation.[http://www.nigeria.gov.ng/NR/exeres/B30C7654-36D9-4C57-837C-1EAB4A103091.htm?id=637 Nigeria Direct] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080214021730/http://www.nigeria.gov.ng/NR/exeres/B30C7654-36D9-4C57-837C-1EAB4A103091.htm?id=637 |date=February 14, 2008 }} 2 May 2007 ===Sale of Virgin's stake and rebranding=== [[File:Nigerian Eagle Airlines logo.png|thumb|Logo used for Nigerian Eagle Airlines.]] On 19 August 2008, [[Virgin Atlantic]] announced that it was "in talks to sell its 49 percent stake in Virgin Nigeria" and reviewing "whether it is appropriate that the Virgin brand should remain linked to Virgin Nigeria”.{{Cite web|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/ceb26f6e-6e17-11dd-b5df-0000779fd18c.html|title=Subscribe to read|website=Financial Times|access-date=2017-08-24}} This followed a dispute which arose after Virgin Nigeria's domestic operations were moved against its will by the Ministry of Transportation to Terminal 2. Virgin Nigeria had twice refused the directive to relocate its domestic operations from the international terminal, citing the Memorandum of Mutual Understanding it had signed with the previous ([[Olusegun Obasanjo]]) administration, and pending appeal in a Lagos High court, as reasons for not complying. On 9 January 2009, Virgin Nigeria announced they would suspend all long haul flights to [[London Gatwick Airport]] and [[Johannesburg]], effective 27 January 2009.{{Cite web |url=http://www.virginnigeria.com/en/ng/press/pr2009-01-09.html |title=Flights Have Now Finished |access-date=2009-07-25 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090603032057/http://www.virginnigeria.com/en/ng/press/pr2009-01-09.html |archive-date=2009-06-03 |dead-url=yes |df= }} On 17 September 2009, Virgin Nigeria announced on their website they had rebranded as '''Nigerian Eagle Airlines'''. Nigerian Eagle Airlines also stated that they planned to focus on domestic and regional flights with further expansion into [[Europe]] and eventually the [[United States of America]].{{Cite web |url=http://www.virginnigeria.com/en/ng/press/pr2009-09-17.html |title=Virgin Nigeria Rebrand As Nigerian Eagle Airlines |access-date=2009-09-18 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090922214606/http://www.virginnigeria.com/en/ng/press/pr2009-09-17.html |archive-date=2009-09-22 |dead-url=yes |df= }} Virgin retained its 49% stake in the new Nigerian Eagle Airlines with the remaining 51% held by Nigerian investors. ===Rebranding as Air Nigeria, and cessation of operations === On 2 June 2010, following the acquisition of a majority share in the airline, [[Jimoh Ibrahim]], the new [[Chairman]], announced that the airline had undergone a further name change to Air Nigeria Development Limited, branded as '''Air Nigeria'''.{{Cite web |url=http://www.virginnigeria.com/en/ng/press/pr2010-07-02.html |title=Nigerian Eagle Airlines Rebrands As Air Nigeria |access-date=2010-06-07 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100612161721/http://www.virginnigeria.com/en/ng/press/pr2010-07-02.html |archive-date=2010-06-12 |dead-url=yes |df= }} On 13 June 2012, the carrier was grounded by regulators for safety checks.http://www.businessweek.com/ap/2012-06/D9VCD5F02.htm On 6 September 2012 Air Nigeria announced that the management had fired its staff ‘for being disloyal' and the airline ceased all its local, regional, and international operations.[http://www.businessdayonline.com/NG/index.php/news/284-breaking-news/47439-hope-of-air-nigerias-return-dims-as-aoc-expires Hope of Air Nigeria’s return dims as AOC expires] Operations ceased on 10 September 2012. == Suspension == On the 19th of September, 2018, the Nigerian government [https://reportsafrique.com/politics/nigeria-suspends-national-carrier-two-months-after-launch/ suspended the plans to launch the Nigeria air indefinitely]. No concise reasons were given for the suspension. == Destinations == {{main|List of Air Nigeria destinations}} ===Codeshare agreements=== * [[Delta Air Lines]] ([[SkyTeam]]){{Cite web |url=http://www.thisdayonline.com/nview.php?id=161186 |title=Nigerian Eagle Signs Code-share Deal with Delta |access-date=2009-12-06 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091218042619/http://www.thisdayonline.com/nview.php?id=161186 |archive-date=2009-12-18 |dead-url=yes |df= }}{{Cite web|url=http://news.delta.com/index.php?s=43&item=1395|title=Delta News Hub|website=news.delta.com|language=en|access-date=2017-08-24}} * [[Kenya Airways]] ([[SkyTeam]])[http://odili.net/news/source/2009/sep/30/229.html Nigerian Eagle Airlines signs Codeshare with Kenya Airways]{{Dead link|date=October 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} == Fleet == [[File:Air Nigeria Boeing 737-300 Iwelumo.jpg|thumb|right|An Air Nigeria [[Boeing 737-300]] at [[Nnamdi Azikiwe International Airport]], [[Abuja]]. IT Services | revenue = [[Euro|€]]2.718 billion (2014){{cite web |url=http://conteudos.ptportugal.pt/Documents/informacao-financeira/RG_PTP_2014_E.PDF |title=Consolidated Report 2014 |accessdate=30 July 2014 |publisher=PT Portugal |archive-url=https://arquivo.pt/wayback/20150509034206/http://conteudos.ptportugal.pt/Documents/informacao%2Dfinanceira/RG_PTP_2014_E.PDF |archive-date=2015-05-09 |dead-url=yes |df= }} | operating_income = €1.053 billion (2014) | net_income = €384.0 million (2014) | assets = €7.400 billion (end 2014) | equity = €1.650 billion (end 2014) | num_employees = 10,701 (end 2014) | parent = [[Altice (company)|Atlice]] | homepage = [https://www.telecom.pt/en-us/pages/default.aspx www.altice.pt] }} '''Altice Portugal''' (formerly known as '''Portugal Telecom''' or '''PT''') is the largest [[telecommunications service provider]] in [[Portugal]]. Since June 2, 2015, the company is a wholly owned subsidiary of [[Altice (company)|Altice Group]], a multinational cable and telecommunications company with a presence in France, Israel, Belgium & Luxembourg, Portugal, French West Indies/Indian Ocean Area and Dominican Republic (“Overseas Territories”), Switzerland, and the United States. Its assets in Portugal were sold to [[Altice (company)|Altice]][ISIN: LU1014539529] in 2015 in a move of its owner, [[Oi (telecommunications)|Oi SA]],[ISIN: BROIBRACNOR1] to reduce debt. The African assets were mostly sold for the same reason. Portugal Telecom, SGPS SA was split in separate companies: PT Portugal (now Altice Portugal) and Pharol (formerly PT SGPS), which owns a 27,5% stake in Oi.{{cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/portugal-telecom-holders-approve-sale-of-portuguese-operations-to-altice-1421958476|title=Portugal Telecom Holders Approve Sale of Portuguese Operations to Altice|first=Patricia|last=Kowsmann|date=22 January 2015|publisher=|accessdate=11 April 2018|via=www.wsj.com}}{{cite web|url=http://www.nasdaq.com/press-release/oi-approval-by-telemar-participacoes-shareholders-of-the-planned-measures-for-the-transaction-goal-20150401-00016|title=Today's Stock Market News and Analysis from Nasdaq.com|author=|date=|website=NASDAQ.com|accessdate=11 April 2018}} == History == The first telephone experiments in Portugal connected [[Carcavelos]] to the Central do Cabo in [[Lisbon]], in 1877. In 1882, the [[Edison Gower-Bell Telephone Company of Europe, Ltd.|Edison Gower-Bell Telephone Company]] was established in both Lisbon and [[Porto]], to explore the respective telephone service concessions. In 1887, the concession was transferred to APT - The Anglo Portuguese Telephone Company, which was kept by the latter until 1968, the year in which the Public Company "Telefones de Lisboa e Porto" (TLP) was created. The Post Office, Telegraphs and Telephones ([[CTT]]) explored until this present day, the telephone service in the rest of the country. For the exploration of [[radiotelegraphy]] and [[wireless telephone (disambiguation)|wireless telephone]], a contract with the Marconi's Wireless Telegraphy Company concession was confirmed in 1922. In 1925, the "Companhia Portuguesa Rádio Marconi" (CPRM) was set up and took on all responsibilities of the previous concession. In 1970, CTT became a Public Company and in 1989, the TLP was transformed into a Limited Company, and was completely controlled by the State. [[File:Cabina telefónica frente a la Catedral de Oporto, Portugal, 2012-05-09, DD 01.JPG|thumb|upright=0.9|APT heritage still in use in [[Porto]]]] In 1992, the Portuguese government and the Public Service Television Corporation [[Rádio e Televisão de Portugal|RTP]] agreed to separate the transmitter network from the rest of the corporation, transferring it to a recently created state-owned company named "Teledifusão de Portugal" (TDP). The purpose of this was to explore a nationwide TV broadcasting network available for any TV station in Portugal to request its services. At the time, RTP (a "native" client of TDP) was having competition for the first time since its creation in the 1950s. [[Sociedade Independente de Comunicação|SIC]] required the services of TDP, but [[Televisão Independente|TVI]] decided to create its own transmitter Network (RETI). In 1992, CTT became a Limited Company with public capital and the Comunicações Nacionais, SPGS, SA (CN) was created, a state holding company responsible for the managing of all state participation within the sector - CTT, TLP, CPRM e TDP. In this same year, the Telecommunications developed by CTT was automatized through the creation of Telecom Portugal, SA, giving CTT the possibility to dedicate itself exclusively to the Post Office. With this, Portugal had its own telecommunications network which was being explored by 3 operators: the TLP explored the telephone services in the Lisbon and Porto areas, Telecom Portugal was responsible for the remaining national, European and Mediterranean communications; and Marconi took hold of international traffic. In 1994, a unique national telecommunications operator was created with the fusion of companies within the CN State holding: Portugal Telecom, SA (PT), with the fusion of Telecom Portugal, TLP and TDP. Portugal Telecom was the only telephone operator in Portugal, being a [[monopoly]], until 1994, when the government gradually retired its control over the corporation and, in 2000, Portugal Telecom became a publicly owned company. Since then, it has held a dominant position in the liberalized Portuguese market. [[Image:Portugal Telecom Lisboa.jpg|right|thumb|200px|Headquarters in Lisbon]] In early 2007, the Portuguese conglomerate, [[Sonae]]'s [[takeover]] offer for Portugal Telecom failed. PT's board rejected an initial bid, worth EUR 11.1 bn, in February 2006. Sonae.com's takeover bid opposed [[Belmiro de Azevedo]] (founder and historical chairman of [[Sonae]] holding company) and his son Paulo Azevedo (then the head officer of [[Sonae.com]] telecommunications operator) to the investor [[José Berardo]] and PT's administrators Zeinal Bava and Henrique Granadeiro.{{clarify|date=July 2011}} In April 2007 the [[European Commission]] gave an ultimatum to the [[Portuguese government]] ordering it to give up on the 500 [[golden share]]s pack that it owned on the company and that enable special veto powers to the government on vital issues. This could give the government a decisive role in the bid by any company to buy Portugal Telecom. In November 2007, Portugal Telecom spun off its media assets ([[PT Multimédia]]), that included [[TV Cabo]] and [[Lusomundo]] Cinemas. In January 2008, the [[European Commission]] began legal proceedings against the Portuguese government over its 'golden share' in incumbent telecoms operator Portugal Telecom. The 500 golden shares with extended voting rights, allowing it to block potential takeover bids, were the reason for the Commission's legal action. Similarly, in November 2005, the Commission had forced the [[Spanish government]] to give up its golden share in the other telecommunications' major player in the [[Iberian Peninsula]], the Spanish telecoms giant [[Telefónica]]. In December 2009, Portugal Telecom purchased RETI. In October 2, 2013, Portugal Telecom and Brazil's [[Oi (telecommunications)|Oi]] said they would combine operations to form a new Brazil-based company with more than 100 million subscribers.{{cite news| url=https://online.wsj.com/news/articles/SB10001424052702304906704579110693710265598| title=Portugal Telecom and Brazil's Oi to Merge | work=The Wall Street Journal}} The resulting company's provisional name is CorpCo. Armando Almeida replaced Zeinal Bava at the helm of Portugal Telecom on August 18, 2014. Zeinal Bava skipped off to Oi in Brazil.[http://algarvedailynews.com/news/3442-portugal-telecom-s-new-chief-to-put-customers-first Portugal Telecom’s new chief 'to put customers first'], Algarve Daily News (18-09-2014) On June 2, 2015, [[Altice (company)|Altice Group]] announced closing of Portugal Telecom acquisition.{{Cite news|url = http://altice.net/wp-content/uploads/2015/06/altice-portugal-telecom-Closing-Announcement-150602.pdf|title = Altice announces closing of Portugal Telecom Acquisition|last = |first = |date = June 2, 2015|work = |access-date = |via = }}{{cite web| date= June 2, 2015 | publisher= [[Agence France-Presse]] and [[Business Insider]]| title=Altice finalises acquisition of Portugal Telecom| access-date=August 1, 2015| url= http://www.businessinsider.com/afp-altice-finalises-acquisition-of-portugal-telecom-2015-6}}. [[Paulo Neves|Paulo Manuel da Conceição Neves]] was appointed as CEO.{{Cite news|url = http://www.telecompaper.com/news/pt-portugal-names-new-management--1091417|title = PT Portugal names new management|last = |first = |date = |work = |access-date = |via = }} On November 21, 2017, Paulo Neves resigns as CEO and it was replaced by Alexandre Filipe Fonseca.{{Cite news|url = https://expresso.sapo.pt/economia/2017-11-21-Altice-Paulo-Neves-sai-da-PT-Alexandre-Fonseca-confirmado-como-presidente-executivo#gs.oQptCEY|title = Altice: Paulo Neves sai da PT, Alexandre Fonseca confirmado como presidente executivo|last = |first = |date = |work = |access-date = |via = }} == Operations == ===Domestic=== Altice owns [[MEO (Portugal)|MEO]], the largest [[landline]] operator in Portugal.{{cite web|url=http://www.telecom.pt/InternetResource/PTSite/UK/Canais/Investidores/Grupo/Estrutura+do+Grupo/estruturacorp.htm|title=Corporate structure|date=1 September 2009|publisher=Portugal Telecom|accessdate=23 January 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/67DQ5lp2N?url=http://www.telecom.pt/InternetResource/PTSite/UK/Canais/Investidores/Grupo/Estrutura+do+Grupo/estruturacorp.htm|archivedate=26 April 2012|df=}} Its operating brands include [[Meo (Portugal)|MEO]], a [[quadruple play]] service provider and [[SAPO (company)|SAPO]], an [[Internet service provider|ISP]] and producer of web content. Portugal Telecom also owns Altice Labs (formerly known as PT Inovação), an [[Information technology|IT services]] and [[research and development]] company; PT Contact, focused in the business of managing [[Contact centre (business)|contact centres]]. === International === Portugal Telecom does not run any international operations, since all have been transferred to [[Oi (telecommunications)|Oi]], in 2014.{{Cite news|url = http://web3.cmvm.pt/sdi/emitentes/docs/fr49864.pdf|title = Oi capital increase|last = |first = |date = |work = |access-date = |via = }} [[Brazil]] was Portugal Telecom's second-largest market. PT agreed to acquire 22.4% of [[Oi (telecommunications)|Telemar Norte Leste (Oi)]], the country's largest telecommunications firm, in July 2010.{{cite news|last=Minder|first=Raphael|title=Telefónica Wins Full Control of Brazil Phone Venture|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/07/29/technology/29vivo.html|accessdate=31 July 2010|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=28 July 2010}} Separately it also had 29% of [[Universo Online|UOL]], a major Brazil-based ISP and [[online service provider]]; and was the sole owner of Dedic, a [[call centre]] operator. PT previously held 29.7% of [[Vivo S.A.|Vivo]], the country's largest mobile phone network, which it controlled jointly with [[Telefónica]]. It agreed however to sell its stake to Telefónica for €7.5 billion in July 2010. Portugal Telecom's other main international assets were based in Africa and Asia, largely in [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]]-speaking nations. Through a 75%-owned investment [[holding company]] Africatel, PT had an effective 18.75% of [[Angola]]'s largest mobile operator Unitel; 30% of Cabo Verde Telecom (CVT) of [[Cape Verde]]; 38.25% of Companhia Santomense de Telecomunicações (CST) of [[São Tomé and Príncipe]]; and 25.5% of the [[Namibia]]n mobile firm [[MTC Namibia|MTC]]. The firm sold a 32% shareholding in [[Méditel]] of Morocco in September 2009.{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/idUKL156934420090901|title=Portugal Telecom, Telefonica sell Meditel stakes|last=Tavares|first=Elisabete|author2=Khalip, Andrei |author3=MacInnes, Judy |date=1 September 2009|work=[[Reuters]]|accessdate=23 January 2010}} In [[Asia]] Portugal Telecom owned 41.1% of Timor Telecom of [[East Timor]]. == Ownership == Altice Portugal is no longer a [[public company|publicly traded company]], since 100% of its capital is owned by [[Altice (company)|Altice Group]]. As of 15 November 2011 its major stockholders were [[Espírito Santo Financial Group]] (11.30%), RS Holding (10.05%), [[Capital Group Companies|Capital Research and Management]] (9.97%), [[Oi (telecommunications)|Oi;k]] (7.00%), [[Caixa Geral de Depósitos]] (6.23%), [[Brandes Investment Partners]] (5.24%) and [[Norges Bank]] (5.01%). After privatization the [[Portuguese government]] owned 500 [[golden share]]s in PT, which carried special rights over the company's management decisions and blocked any one shareholder from holding more than 10% of voting rights within the company.{{cite news|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/2/0a51e156-bd5e-11db-b5bd-0000779e2340.html|title=Sonaecom lifts Portugal Telecom bid|last=Wise|first=Peter|date=16 February 2007|work=[[Financial Times]]|accessdate=23 January 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110609063923/http://www.ft.com/cms/s/2/0a51e156-bd5e-11db-b5bd-0000779e2340.html|archive-date=2011-06-09|dead-url=yes|df=}} The golden shares were the subject of a long running dispute between the government and the [[European Commission]], which alleged that their existence was illegal under [[European Union law|EU law]]. Portugal argued that the shares were in the [[public interest]]. A case brought before the [[European Court of Justice]] by the Commission to force the government to cede its shares resulted in the announcement of their abolition in July 2011.{{cite news|last=Goncalves|first=Sergio|title=Portugal scraps golden shares in utilities|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/07/05/portugal-goldenshares-idUSLDE76414L20110705|accessdate=18 November 2011|date=5 July 2011|author2=Alvarenga, Daniel|agency=[[Reuters]]}} On 2 October 2013 it was reported that Portugal Telecom and Brazil's Oi are to Merge to create a Brazil-based company.{{cite news|last=|first=|title=Portugal Telecom and Brazil's Oi to Merge |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052702304906704579110693710265598|accessdate=2 October 2013|date=2 October 2013|author1=PATRICIA KOWSMANN |author2=ROGERIO JELMAYER|agency=[[Wall Street Journal]]|work=The Wall Street Journal}} Since June 2, 2015, it is a wholly owned subsidiary of [[Altice (company)|Altice Group]], a multinational cable and telecommunications company with a presence in France, Israel, Belgium & Luxembourg, Portugal, French West Indies/Indian Ocean Area and Dominican Republic (“Overseas Territories”) and Switzerland. == Notes == {{reflist|30em}} == External links == * {{official website|https://www.telecom.pt/en-us/pages/default.aspx}} [[Category:Companies formerly listed on the New York Stock Exchange]] [[Category:Telecommunications companies of Portugal]] [[Category:Portuguese brands]] [[Category:Companies established in 1994]] [[Category:Companies based in Lisbon]]

'''Andrea Mazzucchi''' (born March 19, 1966) in [[Rome]] is an [[Italian Americans|Italian American]] entrepreneur, network architect, and computer specialist
He played a significant role in the early development of Internet in [[Italy]], and other countries in Eastern Europe, such as [[Croatia]].
Being interested in the regulatory side, as well as the technical, he also played a key role in the Internet governance of Italy since 1985. He co-founded, in 1998, the [[ccTLD]] ".it" policy board (Naming Authority), where he eventually became Chair of the Board of Directors. In 2004, once the Naming Authority evolved into the Rules Committee, he was one of the appointed members.
Focused since the very beginning toward the [[Open Source]], in 1992 he co-founded Nexus, the first [[ISP]] in Italy based exclusively on [[Linux]] and open technologies.
In 1993, Mazzucchi co-founded Gedi, one of the first companies in Italy for [[distance learning]].
In 1995, he founded Istria On Line, the first ISP in Croatia, and worked on Internet pilot projects in [[Bulgaria]] and [[Hungary]], mostly establishing [[TCP/IP]] over [[X.25]] Internet connections for international businesses.
He is also an active member of the Internet community, being co-founder, with [[Giancarlo Livraghi]], of [[ALCEI]], initially conceived as the Italian branch of [[Electronic Frontier Foundation|EFF]]. Moreover, he is co-founder of the Italian Chapter of [[Internet Society|ISOC]] where he served on the first Board of Directors.

'''Biocell Center''' is an international company specializing in the [[cryopreservation]] and private banking of [[amniotic fluid]] [[stem cells]].<ref>{{cite web|title=World's First Amniotic Stem Cell Bank Opens In Medford|first1=Curt|last1=Nickisch|publisher=WBUR News|url=http://www.wbur.org/news/2009/10/22/stem-cell-bank|date=22 October 2009|access-date=10 June 2018}}</ref> The company is headquartered in Italy with several international locations and is involved with numerous partnerships and research studies of [[amniotic stem cells|amniotic fluid stem cells]].<ref>[http://www.thelancet.com/search/results?searchTerm=simoni&fieldName=Authors&year=1983&volume=&page=&journalFromWhichSearchStarted=&sort=date&order=desc&collectionName=Medline (Lancet, 1983)]</ref><ref>[https://www.tomalab.com/repository/cellulestaminali.doc]</ref>
In 2008, Biocell Center opened the first amniotic fluid stem [[cell bank]] in the world, and in 2009 it opened the first amniotic fluid stem cell bank in the United States for private storage of stem cells obtained during genetic [[amniocentesis]]<ref>[http://www.stem-cells-news.com/1/2009/05/italy-stem-cells-from-amniotic-liquid-new-hopes/ ITALY - Stem cells from amniotic liquid, new hopes] Published by Stem Man 5 May 2009, Latest Stem Cells News”</ref>
Biocell Center’s Italian headquarters in [[Busto Arsizio]] and [[Milan]] (Italy),<ref>{{youtube|HFl6AMwRVes|Biocell Center - Intro}}</ref> are managed by company president [[Marco Reguzzoni]] and scientific director [[Giuseppe Simoni]], and additional subsidiaries are located in [[Lugano]] ([[Switzerland]]), and [[Natick, Massachusetts]] (USA) - [[Boston]] area,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.freshnews.com/news/230464/european-biotech-company-biocell-center-opens-first-us-facility-preservation-amniotic-st |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-10-30 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100221142752/http://www.freshnews.com/news/230464/european-biotech-company-biocell-center-opens-first-us-facility-preservation-amniotic-st |archivedate=2010-02-21 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.luminogenics.com/blog/2009/10/22/massachusetts-life-sciences-center |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-10-30 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100221063253/http://www.luminogenics.com/blog/2009/10/22/massachusetts-life-sciences-center |archivedate=2010-02-21 |df= }}</ref>
Biocell Center is currently collaborating with [[Harvard University]] and the [[Caritas Christi Health Care]] hospital network on amniotic stem cell research.{{citation needed|date=June 2018}}

'''Bodo B. Schlegelmilch''' is Chair of the [[Association of MBAs]] (AMBA) and Professor and Chair of the Institute for International Marketing at WU,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wu.ac.at/en/imm/|title=International Marketing Management|website=WU (Vienna University of Economics and Business)}}</ref> [[Vienna University of Economics and Business]], Vienna, Austria. He also serves on the Executive Board of the American Chamber of Commerce in Austria<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.amcham.at/|title=AmCham Austria - American Chamber of Commerce in Austria|website=www.amcham.at}}</ref> and the Board of Trustees at the Academy of Marketing Science.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ams-web.org/|title=Academy of Marketing Science|website=www.ams-web.org}}</ref> Schlegelmilch has been awarded Fellowships from the [[Academy of International Business]], the Academy of Marketing Science<ref>{{cite web|url=http:h]]//www.ams-web.org/|title=Academy of Marketing Science|website=www.ams-web.org}}</ref> and the [[Chartered Institute of Marketing]].
== Biography ==
Schlegelmilch obtained his bachelor's degree at the University of Applied Sciences in [[Cologne]], his master's degree, Ph.D. and D.Litt. from the [[University of Manchester]] and an honorary Ph.D. from [[Thammasat University]] in Bangkok. He served as founding Dean of the WU Executive Academy at the Vienna University of Economics and Business,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://executiveacademy.at/|title=WU Executive Academy Wien|website=WU Executive Academy}}</ref> and Editor in Chief of the [[American Marketing Association]]'s ''Journal of International Marketing''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.ama.org/publications/JournalOfInternationalMarketing/Pages/current-issue.aspx|title=Latest Research|website=ama.org}}</ref>
Starting at Deutsche Bank and Procter & Gamble, he continued his career at the University of Edinburgh and the University of California, Berkeley. Appointments as British Rail Chair of Marketing at the University of Wales and Professor of International Business at Thunderbird School of Global Management followed.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://bach.wu.ac.at/d/research/ma/3628/#rg_2|title=FIDES|website=wu.ac.at}}</ref>
== Publications == Schlegelmilch has been listed among the world's most prolific authors of international marketing.<ref>Leonidou, L. C., Katsikeas, C. S., Samiee, S. & Aykol, B. (2018). "International Marketing Research: A State-of-the-Art Review and the Way Forward." In Advances in Global Marketing (pp. 3-33). Springer International Publishing. {{ISBN|978-3-319-61385-7}}.</ref> He has published books on different marketing and management topics,<ref>https://scholar.google.at/citations?view_op=search_authors&mauthors=bodo+schlegelmilch&hl=en&oi=ao</ref> including two widely noted textbooks:
*Schlegelmilch, Bodo B. ''Global Marketing Strategy: An Executive Digest''. 2016. Cham: Springer, 2015 {{ISBN|9783319262772}}. The various editions of this book are held in 216 libraries, according to [[WorldCat]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.worldcat.org/title/global-marketing-strategy-an-executive-digest/oclc/922910877&referer=brief_results|title=Global marketing strategy: an executive digest|first=Bodo B|last=Schlegelmilch|date=27 May 2018|publisher=|via=Open WorldCat}}</ref> *Keegan, Warren J., and Bodo B. Schlegelmilch. ''Global Marketing Management: A European Perspective''. Harlow, England: Financial Times Prentice Hall, 2001. The various editions of this book are held in 688 libraries, according to WorldCat.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.worldcat.org/title/global-marketing-management-a-european-perspective/oclc/44868912&referer=brief_results|title=Global marketing management: a European perspective|first1=Warren J|last1=Keegan|first2=Bodo B|last2=Schlegelmilch|date=27 May 2018|publisher=Financial Times Prentice Hall|via=Open WorldCat}}</ref>
His research spans international marketing strategy, corporate social responsibility and cultural differences<ref>https://scholar.google.at/citations</ref> and has been published in a variety of academic journals (e.g. Strategic Management Journal,<ref>Ambos, Björn, Schlegelmilch, Bodo B. (2007). Innovation and Control in the Multinational Firm: A Comparison of Political and Contingency Approaches. Strategic Management Journal. 28 (5): 473–486.</ref> Journal of International Business Studies<ref>Awanis, Sandra, Schlegelmilch, Bodo B., Chi Cui, Charles. (2017). Asia's Materialists: Reconciling Collectivism and Materialism. Journal of International Business Studies, 48 (8): 964-991.</ref> and Journal of the Academy of Marketing Science).<ref>Szöcs, Ilona, Schlegelmilch, Bodo B., Rusch, Thomas, Shamma, Hamed M. (2016). Linking Cause Assessment, Corporate Philanthropy, and Corporate Reputation. Journal of the Academy of Marketing Science. 44 (3): 376–396.</ref>

'''Carisa Bianchi''' is the former president and CEO of the [[Los Angeles]] branch of advertising agency [[TBWA\Chiat\Day]].
Bianchi graduated from [[Stanford University]] and [[California Polytechnic State University]] where she majored in communications and [[political science]], with the original intention of working for the [[CIA]].<ref>http://www.adotas.com/2006/01/tbwachiatdays-carisa-bianchi-lives-in-perpetual-moti/</ref> Unable to find a suitable position in the CIA, she joined the advertising firm of [[Benton & Bowles]] in Los Angeles, working on [[Continental Airlines]] and Homes Savings of America. After two years, she left to join [[Doyle Dane Bernbach]], working on GTE and The Southern California Gas Company. In 1989, she joined Chiat\Day Los Angeles, where she spent eight years working with clients such as [[Energizer Batteries]], [[Sony PlayStation]], Cherry Coke and Sparkletts bottled water. Under her guidance, the [[Energizer Bunny]] campaign became one of the most successful advertising campaigns in U.S. history. The Sony PlayStation was also one of the most successful platform launches in the history of video games.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.i20events.com/speakers.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-06-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100925204630/http://www.i20events.com/speakers.html |archivedate=2010-09-25 |df= }}</ref>
In 1998, Bianchi became the Managing Director of the newly re-opened TBWA\Chiat\Day office in San Francisco. In 2001, she was named one of [[Advertising Age]]’s "Women to Watch". She moved back to Los Angeles in 2002 to become Chief Strategy Officer, overseeing all strategic initiatives, including Account Planning, Business Development and the Disruption and Connections initiative. In 2005, she was promoted to President of the Los Angeles office. In her first year as president, the agency launched The Disruption Consultancy, won the [[Visa Inc.|Visa]] account, won a record number of Grand [[EFFIE]]s and was named Adweek’s Agency of the Year.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.effie.org/about/global_committee/bianchi |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-06-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100616214548/http://www.effie.org/about/global_committee/bianchi |archivedate=2010-06-16 |df= }}</ref>
In 2006, TBWA was named Global Agency of the Year by Adweek and Agency of the Year by SHOOT and Boards magazines.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.effie.org/about/global_committee/bianchi |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-06-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100616214548/http://www.effie.org/about/global_committee/bianchi |archivedate=2010-06-16 |df= }}</ref>
Bianchi is an avid runner who competes in marathons.<ref>http://www.athlinks.com/results/45628/67549/40469672/f10/The-San-Francisco-Marathon-2008.aspx</ref>

'''Continued process verification''' (CPV) is the collection and analysis of end-to-end production components and processes data to ensure product outputs are within predetermined quality limits. In 2011 the [[Food and Drug Administration]] published a report<ref>{{cite web |title= Process Validation: General Principles and Practices |url=http://www.fda.gov/downloads/Drugs/Guidances/UCM070336.pdf |publisher=FDA |accessdate= 3 November 2014}}</ref> outlining best practices regarding business process validation in the [[pharmaceutical industry]]. Continued process verification is outlined in this report as the third stage in [[process validation]]. Its central purpose is to ensure that processes are in a constant state of control, thus ensuring final product quality. Central to effective CPV is a method with which to identify unwanted process inconsistencies in order to execute corrective or preventative measures. Once quality standards are set in place they must be monitored with regular frequency to confirm those parameters are being met. Continued process verification not only helps protect consumers from production faults, but business also see benefits in implementing a CPV program. Should product outputs not match target standards it can be very costly to investigate the problem source without existing CPV data.
==Vital components of continued process verification== * An alert system to identify process malfunctions that lead to deviations from quality standards. * A framework for gathering and analyzing data of final product quality and process consistency. Analysis should include source materials consistency and manufacturing equipment condition; and data should be collected in a format that allows for long term trend analysis as well as intra-production quality analysis. * Continued review of quality qualification standards and process reliability. Departures from any predetermined standards should be flagged for review by trained personnel and appropriate measures undertaken to restore end-to-end quality standards.<ref>{{cite web|title=Trust but Verify (Continuously)|url=http://www2.emersonprocess.com/siteadmincenter/PM%20Articles/ART-Trust-but-Verify.pdf|publisher=Pharmaceutical Manufacturing|accessdate=3 November 2014}}</ref>
==Data collection and analysis== Crucial in effective CPV implementation is an appropriate data collection procedure. Data must allow for statistical analytics and trend analysis of process consistency and capability.<ref>{{cite web|title=Continued Process Verification (CPV)|url=http://www.atris-systems.com/216.0.html|publisher=Atris Information Systems|accessdate=3 November 2014}}</ref> A correctly implemented procedure will minimize overreactions to individual production outlier events and guarantee genuine process inconsistency are detected. While production variability can sometimes be obvious and even casually identified the FDA recommends using statistical tools to quantitatively detect problems and identify root causes. Initially, continued process verification should be based on quality standards established in the design phase. After a period of time variations can be detected by identifying deviation from historical data using statistical tools. Furthermore, these same tools can also be used to identify opportunities to optimize processes that may pre-emptively increase quality reliability.<ref>{{cite web|title=A Case for Stage 3 Continued Process Verification|url=http://www.pharmamanufacturing.com/articles/2014/stage3-continued-process-verification|publisher=Pharmaceutical Manufacturing|accessdate=3 November 2014}}</ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2016}} {{Use New Zealand English|date=November 2016}} '''Sir Dryden Thomas Spring DSc (Honoris Causa), DistFInstD''' (born 6 October 1939) of Tauranga, is a [[New Zealand]] businessman, who was Chairman of the [[New Zealand Dairy Board]] from 1989 to 1998 and Chairman of New Zealand Dairy Group from 1982 to 1987, Chairman Of ANZ New Zealand from 2007 to 2012. He is a Laureate of the New Zealand Business Hall of Fame and a Distinguished Fellow of the Institute of Directors in New Zealand. ==Career==
He became President of The NZ Sharemilkers Association in 1967, President of Waikato Federated Farmers in 1972 and a director of New Zealand Dairy Group in 1973 at the age of 33.<ref>[http://www.westpac.co.nz/olcontent/olcontent.nsf/Content/17+April+2003+9am Sir Dryden Receives Accolade] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081018084933/http://www.westpac.co.nz/olcontent/olcontent.nsf/Content/17+April+2003+9am |date=18 October 2008 }}</ref> In 1973 he was chosen as New Zealands Outstanding Young Man Of The Year by New Zealand Jaycees. In 2003 he was awarded the Holden Lifetime Achievement Award for service to the Dairy Industry. Spring was Chairman of ANZ National Bank from April 2007 to June 2012, having formerly served as a director of the [[National Bank of New Zealand]] Limited. He is a Distinguished Fellow of the Institute of Directors in New Zealand, a Life Member of Waikato Federated Farmers and a Distinguished Fellow of Massey University Academy of Agriculture. Spring was awarded a Doctor of Science (Honoris Causa) by Massey University in 2000<ref>[http://www.massey.org.nz/massey/about-massey/calendar/officers-and-staff-of-the-university/honorary-graduates.cfm Honorary Graduates - Massey University] Retrieved 11 January 2013 and an Honorary Doctorate by Waikato University in 2014.. .</ref>
Spring formerly held a number of directorships including Nufarm Ltd., Maersk NZ Ltd., Affco Ltd., Fletcher Building Ltd., Sky City Entertainment Group Ltd., Port of Tauranga Ltd; Northport Ltd., Deputy Chairman of Goodman Fielder Ltd., Chairman of Ericcson NZ Ltd. Chairman Of Tenon Ltd., Deputy Chairman Of Ports Of Auckland Ltd., Deputy Chairman of The Rural Banking and Finance Corp of New Zealand. He was formerly a member of The APEC Eminent Persons Group, which in 1993 drafted the APEC Vision of Free and Open Trade in the Asia Pacific, a member of APEC Business Advisory Council, Chairman of Asia New Zealand Foundation, and also a founding trustee of the New Zealand Business and Parliamentary Trust.<ref>[http://www.anznational.co.nz/about/drydenspring.aspx Sir Dryden Spring]</ref>
==Honours and family== Spring was awarded a New Zealand Commemoration Medal in 1990. He was appointed a [[Knight Bachelor]] in the [[1994 Birthday Honours|1994 Queen's Birthday Honours]], for services to the dairy industry.<ref>[http://www.london-gazette.co.uk/issues/53697/supplements/33 ''London Gazette'' (supplement), No. 53697, 10 June 1994]. Retrieved 11 January 2013.</ref> He is descended from the [[Spring family]] of Ballyraemeen, Kerry, Ireland. He was appointed a Paul Harris Fellow by Rotary International in 1911. He was inducted as a Laureate of the New Zealand Business Hall of Fame in 2013. He received an Honorary Doctorate from Waikato University in 2014

{{Use South African English|date=July 2018}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2018}} {{Infobox magazine | title = Entrepreneur Magazine South Africa | editor_title = Managing Editor | editor = Nadine Todd | category = Business | publisher = Andrew Honey | founded = 2006 | country = South Africa | website = {{URL|http://www.entrepreneurmag.co.za}} }}
Published by Entrepreneur Media SA (Pty) Ltd, ''[http://entrepreneurmag.co.za/ '''Entrepreneur''']'' [http://entrepreneurmag.co.za/ '''''magazine'''''] is a premium South African business magazine. Launched in 2006, it is published under license from [[Entrepreneur Magazine|'''Entrepreneur Media Inc'''.]]<ref>[http://www.entrepreneur.com Entrepreneur.com]</ref> US, America’s top-selling business magazine.
Targeted at business owners and key decision makers, the monthly South African publication is a ‘how to’ handbook for building companies.
Each issue of the magazine delivers relevant, incisive, high-quality content that not only inspires entrepreneurs to achieve their own business success, but delivers a ‘call to action’ as well. Each issue balances inspiring local success stories that readers can learn valuable business lessons from, with reference guide-like articles that offer actionable steps entrepreneurs can implement immediately.
Entrepreneurs who have been featured in the magazine include Vusi Thembekwayo, [[Vinny Lingham|'''Vinny Lingham''']], [[Gil Oved|'''Gil Oved''']], [[Ran Neu-Ner|'''Ran Neu-Ner''']] and '''[[Adrian Gore]]'''.
== Background ==
The magazine was launched in [[South Africa|'''South Africa''']] in April 2006 by local publisher and founder of Smart Business Solutions (Pty) Ltd, Andrew Honey. Andrew Honey is the CEO of '''[http://www.thinksales.co.za/ ThinkSales Corporation]''' and Entrepreneur Media SA which published '''Entrepreneur Magazine''', the number one selling consumer business magazine in South Africa. He is of a select group of entrepreneurs globally who have sold a business plan and raised traditional capital to launch a company. Today he owns 25% of two companies.
ThinkSales Corporation, a leading revenue growth consultancy and training company has worked with over 600 leading South African companies since 2010 and has hosted over 3 000 delegates at the annual '''[https://convention.thinksales.co.za/ Sales Leadership Conventions]'''.
== Editorial content ==
The editorial mix features mainly medium length "how-to" articles which are divided into the following main categories: * Information on how to start or buy a business with examples from local South African entrepreneurs as they launch their businesses * Information on how to improve an existing business. This section includes content that focuses on a number of key disciplines including leadership and management, sales and marketing, financial management and technology * Information on self-development, motivation and personal finance.
Each issue also carries a number of business case studies and profiles on successful local and international entrepreneurs. Many of the articles carried are written by leading experts in South Africa and the world, notably:
* Greg Fisher: Entrepreneurship lecturer at the [[University of Washington]], [[Seattle, Washington|Seattle]] United States and the Gordon Institute of Business, [[Johannesburg]], South Africa<ref>[http://www.fisherg.blogspot.com Greg Fisher's blog]</ref>{{Nonspecific|date=September 2008}} * [[Brian Tracy]]: Best-selling author, speaker and coach<ref>[http://www.briantracy.com Brian Tracy International]</ref>{{Nonspecific|date=September 2008}} * [[Robert Kiyosaki]]: Author of best-selling series ''[[Rich Dad, Poor Dad]]''<ref>[http://www.richdad.com Rich Dad]</ref>{{Nonspecific|date=September 2008}} * [[Guy Kawasaki]]: Author of ''Art of the Start''<ref>[http://www.guykawasaki.com Guy Kawasaki Website]</ref>{{Nonspecific|date=September 2008}}

'''External risks''' are generally something that is uncontrollable by the first party.
==In contract law== In [[contract law]], are risks that are produced by a non-human source and are beyond [[human]] control. They are unexpected but happen regularly enough in a general population to be broadly predictable, and may be the subject of [[casualty insurance]]. Good examples of external risks are [[natural disasters]] such as [[earthquakes]] and [[volcanoes]].
[[Insurance]] adjusters analyze external risks on a normal basis. Measuring risks of the environment is common practice throughout [[insurance claims]]. As far as claims go, most external risks, or an "[[Act of God]]", are protected by [[property insurance]].
==In project management== In [[project management]]; Risks that are external to the project and the project manager cannot control. Good examples of external risks are changes in government [[legislation]], changes in [[strategy]] from senior managers, and the [[economy]].
==Common examples<ref> {{cite journal |title=External Events |journal=Information Security Handbook |url=http://ishandbook.bsewall.com/risk/Assess/Risk/External_Events.html}}</ref>== * [[Hurricanes]] * [[Earthquakes]] * [[Tornadoes]] * [[Floods]] * Volcanic Eruptions * [[Lightning]] * [[Fire]] * [[Disease]] (such as pandemics/epidemics) * Environmental Hazards (pollution) * Civil Disruptions (vandalism, terrorism)
==Assessing external risks== Three separate aspects should be analyzed when determining the amount of external risk that exists.
# '''Frequency of Occurrence''' - What are the odds of an external risk occurring in your situation? Do similar risk situations happen often in your area? This assesses the probability of the external risk. # '''Duration of the Occurrence''' - Over what time period will the external risk last? How long will the affected party be at an altered state due to this risk? This assesses the amount of time that would be lost due to the risk and its effects. # '''Loss of Assets''' - What types of property could be damaged or destroyed from this risk? This assesses the state of property and assets after the external risk occurs.
==References== {{Reflist}} *Giddens, Anthony (1999). “Risk and Responsibility”. ''Modern Law Journal'', Vol. 62 No. 1, p. 4.

[[Federal Security Service]] (FSB) | rank = [[Lieutenant colonel]] }} '''Gennady Vladimirovich Gudkov''' ({{lang-ru|Генна́дий Влади́мирович Гудко́в}}; b. 15 August 1956 in [[Kolomna]], [[Moscow Oblast]], [[Russian SFSR]], [[Soviet Union]]){{cite web |url=http://gudkov.ru/%D0%B1%D0%B8%D0%BE%D0%B3%D1%80%D0%B0%D1%84%D0%B8%D1%8F/ |script-title=ru:Биография Геннадия Владимировича Гудкова |publisher=gudkov.ru |language=Russian |archivedate=28 October 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Bk0d2DBL?url=http://gudkov.ru/%D0%B1%D0%B8%D0%BE%D0%B3%D1%80%D0%B0%D1%84%D0%B8%D1%8F/ |accessdate=27 October 2012 |deadurl=no |df= }} is a [[Russia]]n politician and businessman. ''[[The Moscow Times]]'' described him in 2012 as "one of parliament's most vocal and charismatic critics" of President [[Vladimir Putin]].{{cite web |url=http://www.themoscowtimes.com/news/article/duma-kicks-out-kremlin-critic/468176.html |title=Duma Kicks Out Kremlin Critic |author=Alexander Bratersky |date=17 September 2012 |work=The Moscow Times |archivedate=28 October 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Bk1YGb0C?url=http://www.themoscowtimes.com/news/article/duma-kicks-out-kremlin-critic/468176.html |accessdate=27 October 2012 |deadurl=no |df= }} == Background == Gudkov received a degree in languages from Kolomna State Pedagogical Institute in 1978. He joined the [[KGB]], the [[Soviet Union]]'s national security agency, in 1981, working there for the next decade and finishing at the rank of lieutenant colonel.{{cite web |url=https://www.economist.com/blogs/easternapproaches/2012/09/russian-politics |title=Why Gennady Gudkov was expelled from the Duma |author=J.Y. |date=17 September 2012 |work=The Economist |archivedate=28 October 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6BjzfhmNG?url=http://www.economist.com/blogs/easternapproaches/2012/09/russian-politics |accessdate=27 October 2012 |deadurl=no |df= }} He later held a post in the [[Federal Security Service (Russia)|Federal Security Service]] until 2001.{{cite web |url=https://news.yahoo.com/russia-expels-anti-putin-lawmaker-whos-next-113639782.html |title=Russia expels anti-Putin lawmaker; who's next? |author=Nataliya Vasilyeva |date=14 September 2012 |agency=Associated Press |archivedate=28 October 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Bk4nAb1B?url=http://news.yahoo.com/russia-expels-anti-putin-lawmaker-whos-next-113639782.html |accessdate=27 October 2012 |deadurl=no |df= }} == Duma career == Gudkov was first elected to the [[State Duma]] in a by-election of the Kolomna 106th District on 18 March 2001, joining the [[People's Party of the Russian Federation]]. Gudkov won the seat again in the [[Russian legislative election, 2003|2003]] and [[Russian legislative election, 2007|2007 legislative elections]]. Gudkov was serving as deputy chairman of the parliamentary Committee on Security during the 2002 [[Moscow theater hostage crisis]], in which 40-50 [[Chechnya|Chechen]] Islamist separatists took over a theater holding 850 people.{{cite web |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P1-68949717.html |title=Rebels Threaten Hostages in Moscow |author=Eric Engleman |date=24 October 2002 |publisher=Associated Press {{Subscription required|via=[[HighBeam Research]]}}|accessdate=27 October 2012}} He blamed the failure of security forces to prevent the attack on a systematic destruction of state security institutions following the fall of the Soviet Union.{{cite web |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-392403.html |title=Putin Takes Hard Line on Terror, Stays Silent on Use of Deadly Gas; Russian Leader Vows to Pursue Chechens' Sponsors and Financial Backers |author=Peter Baker and Susan B. Glasser |date=29 October 2002 |work=The Washington Post |publisher= {{Subscription required|via=[[HighBeam Research]]}}|accessdate=27 October 2012}} In 2004, he denied allegations that Russia was responsible for the death of former Chechen president [[Zelimkhan Yandarbiyev]], stating that the KGB's overseas assassination squad had long been disbanded.{{cite web |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-113662600.html |title=Two Russian Agents Charged in Death of Former Chechen President |author=Mark McDonald |date=27 February 2004 |publisher=Knight Ridder/Tribune Business News {{Subscription required|via=[[HighBeam Research]]}}|accessdate=28 October 2012}} Following the [[2004 Nazran raid|Nazran raid]], in which Chechen rebels killed 90 people at police facilities in [[Ingushetia]], Gudkov supported President Vladimir Putin's firings of top military officials, stating, "[t]he general staff made serious mistakes regarding the military structures' actions in Chechnya."{{cite web |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P1-96576425.html |title=Russian President Shakes Up Top Military |author=Maria Danilova |date=19 July 2004 |publisher=Associated Press {{Subscription required|via=[[HighBeam Research]]}}|accessdate=28 October 2012}} He stated that "This will go on until we ourselves learn how to prevent terrorist acts, until we learn how to carry out effective operations to destroy terrorists"{{cite web |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-199818.html |title=Chechen Conflict Now Rages Beyond Russia's Expectations |author=David E. Hoffman |date=28 October 2012 |work=The Washington Post |publisher= {{Subscription required|via=[[HighBeam Research]]}}|accessdate=28 October 2012}} and called for better pay for security forces to attract better quality personnel and prevent corruption, stating that the latter may have contributed to the [[Beslan school hostage crisis]].{{cite web |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P1-100393466.html |title=Analysis: Inefficiency and corruption bedevil attempts to prevent more terrorist attacks in Russia |author=Robert Siegel |date=28 October 2012 |publisher=National Public Radio {{Subscription required|via=[[HighBeam Research]]}}|accessdate=28 October 2012}} He also supported a law allowing undercover security officers to commit illegal acts such as buying guns or drugs in the course of their duties.{{cite web |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P1-102261039.html |title=Bill Lets Undercover Police to Break the Law |author=Oksana Yablokova |date=9 November 2004 |work=St. Petersburg Times |publisher= {{Subscription required|via=[[HighBeam Research]]}}|accessdate=28 October 2012}} === Opposition to Putin === In March 2004, following a weak performance by the People's Party in the recent legislative elections, Gudkov succeeded {{Interlanguage link multi|Gennady Raikov|2=ru|3=Райков, Геннадий Иванович|preserve=1}} as chairman of the party.{{cite web |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P1-93035818.html |title=Unsuccessful Parties Turn on Leaders |author=Oksana Yablokova |date=31 March 2004 |work=The Moscow Times |publisher= {{Subscription required|via=[[HighBeam Research]]}}|accessdate=27 October 2012}} Gudkov later became a member of Putin's [[United Russia]] party, before switching in 2007 to the populist [[Just Russia]] party, many of whose members oppose Putin.{{cite web |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-302699576.html |title=Russian Duma expels anti-Putin lawmaker. Sign of a coming crackdown? |author=Fred Weir |date=14 September 2012 |work=The Christian Science Monitor |publisher= {{Subscription required|via=[[HighBeam Research]]}}|accessdate=28 October 2012}} In September of that year, he criticized a bill supported by United Russia allowing [[Gazprom]], [[Transneft]], and other corporations to train and arm private security forces, calling it a [[Pandora's box]].{{cite web |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-169310021.html |title=Moscow's mercenaries |date=1 September 2007 |work=Foreign Policy |publisher= {{Subscription required|via=[[HighBeam Research]]}}|accessdate=28 October 2012}} In October, he complained that United Russia "will not allow opponents" and that Russia was becoming a [[one-party state]],{{cite web |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-169843507.html |title=Power To The Party |author=Owen Matthews and Anna Nemtsova |date=22 October 2007 |work=Newsweek |publisher= {{Subscription required|via=[[HighBeam Research]]}}|accessdate=28 October 2012}} and in December 2008, he sought to amend and clarify a Duma bill greatly expanding the definition of treason.{{cite web |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P1-159354047.html |title=Familiar fear as Russia redefines treason Law could silence government critics |author=Michael Schwirtz |date=22 December 2008 |work=International Herald Tribune |publisher= {{Subscription required|via=[[HighBeam Research]]}}|accessdate=28 October 2012}} In March 2009, he criticized legislation by [[Dmitry Medvedev]] to ban political parties with less than a 7% nationwide vote from parliament, saying that "only an incorrigible optimist could consider that a pro-democracy move".{{cite web |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1A1-D976EC7G2.html |title=Minor parties may get nominal Duma seats |date=27 March 2009 |publisher=Associated Press {{Subscription required|via=[[HighBeam Research]]}}|accessdate=28 October 2012}} In October 2011, Gudkov said that due to lack of free debate, "a huge negative energy among the public ready to explode any moment".{{cite web |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-269453816.html |title=Back to the U.S.S.R |author=Owen Matthews and Anna Nemtsova |date=17 October 2011 |work=Newsweek |publisher= {{Subscription required|via=[[HighBeam Research]]}}|accessdate=28 October 2012}} The following month, he broke ranks with his party's moderate criticism of Putin and warned that major street protests could result if United Russia committed electoral fraud in the impending election. In the speech, Gudkov stated that "our elections are a mix of abuse of administrative resources and work going ahead at full speed to ensure falsification". Footage of the speech became a popular video on Russian blogs.{{cite web |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-30139976.html |title=Shocked Putin greeted with boos and jeers at the big fight |date=22 November 2011 |work=The Independent |publisher= {{Subscription required|via=[[HighBeam Research]]}}|accessdate=28 October 2012}} Over the next year, Gudkov became a frequent participant and leader in public [[2011–2012 Russian protests|protests against Putin]]. In January 2012, a secret recording of a conversation between Gudkov and politician [[Vladimir Ryzhkov]] was released in which the two appeared to discuss how to undermine other anti-Putin forces; the two called it a plot to sow distrust between opposition groups.{{cite web |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-30530249.html |title=Putin in broadside against his critics and opponents |author=Daniel McLaughlin |date=20 January 2012 |work=The Irish Times |publisher= {{Subscription required|via=[[HighBeam Research]]}}|accessdate=28 October 2012}} In June, Gudkov's son [[Dmitry Gudkov]], also a Duma deputy, led a [[filibuster]] against a bill allowing large fines for anti-government protesters.{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/06/23/world/europe/ponomarev-works-to-change-russia-from-the-inside.html?_r=0 |title=Working Russia’s Streets, and Its Halls of Power |author=David M. Herszenhorn |date=23 June 2012 |work=The New York Times |archivedate=26 October 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6BhgDjTxQ?url=http://www.nytimes.com/2012/06/23/world/europe/ponomarev-works-to-change-russia-from-the-inside.html?_r=1& |accessdate=22 October 2012 |deadurl=no |df= }} Gennady Gudkov also spoke against the bill, stating that by removing outlets for protest, the legislation was putting Russia on "a sure path to a civil war".{{cite web |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1A1-9b5ad90168d0473fae9f0ecbb1a96462.html |title=Russian parliament approves harsh bill on protests |author=Vladimir Isachenkov |date=5 June 2012 |publisher=Associated Press {{Subscription required|via=[[HighBeam Research]]}}|accessdate=28 October 2012}} ''[[The Economist]]'' described the filibuster as "the most striking act of parliamentary defiance in the Putin era". Following Gudkov's opposition, his private security firm, Oskord, became the target of "a campaign of raids and investigations from a variety of bodies, from the fire department to the Moscow architectural committee". Permission for its guards to carry firearms was revoked, making its usual security operations difficult. Gudkov estimated in July that he had lost 40% of his business.{{cite web |url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-295314886.html |title=Gudkovs, bad cops; Russian politics |date=7 July 2012 |work=The Economist |publisher= {{Subscription required|via=[[HighBeam Research]]}}|accessdate=28 October 2012}} == Expulsion from Duma == In August 2012, a special committee of the Duma was formed to investigate allegations that Gudkov had violated parliamentary rules by making money from the construction firm Kolomensky Stroitel while also holding his seat.{{cite web |url=http://articles.latimes.com/2012/sep/15/world/la-fg-russia-opposition-20120915 |title=Russian opposition lawmaker ousted from parliament |author=Sergei L. Loiko |date=27 October 2012 |work=Los Angeles Times |archivedate=28 October 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Bk210U7P?url=http://articles.latimes.com/2012/sep/15/world/la-fg-russia-opposition-20120915 |accessdate=27 October 2012 |deadurl=no |df= }} The [[Prosecutor General of Russia|Prosecutor General]] and [[Investigative Committee of Russia|Investigative Committee]] presented evidence that Gudkov had broken anti-corruption laws, and the minutes of a Kolomensky Stroitel meeting with Gudkov's signature was given as evidence of his business activity. On 15 September 2012, Gudkov was stripped of his seat in the Duma by a vote of 291 to 150. Gudkov called the vote a farce, saying "This is a reprisal. It is not a court."{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-19601752 |title=Russian Duma expels anti-Putin MP Gennady Gudkov |date=14 September 2012 |publisher=BBC News |archivedate=28 October 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Bk2J5OfD?url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-19601752 |accessdate=27 October 2012 |deadurl=no |df= }} A Just Russia party leader [[Sergei Mironov]] described Gudkov's expulsion as "unlawful revenge". [[United Russia]] Deputy [[Andrei Isayev]] stated that Gudkov had to be stripped of his seat, arguing, "People expect fairness: Everyone is equal in the eyes of the law. We cannot undermine that hope of our people." Analysts described the vote as part of a broader crackdown against Putin's critics, noting the recent charges against anti-corruption activist [[Alexey Navalny]].{{cite news |url=https://news.yahoo.com/unlikely-putin-foe-faces-ouster-russia-assembly-093756790.html |title=Unlikely Putin foe faces ouster from Russia assembly |author=Alissa de Carbonnel |agency=Reuters |date=6 September 2012 |publisher=Yahoo! |archivedate=28 October 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Bk4QUfck?url=http://news.yahoo.com/unlikely-putin-foe-faces-ouster-russia-assembly-093756790.html |accessdate=27 October 2012 |deadurl=no |df= }}{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/09/16/world/europe/anti-putin-protesters-march-in-moscow-russia.html?_r=1 |title=Undaunted by Arrests, the Opposition Marches Against Putin |author1=Ellen Barry |authorlink=Ellen Barry (journalist) |author2=David Herszenhorn |date=15 September 2012|work=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=22 September 2012}} ''[[The Economist]]'' wrote that "like, in a way, Mikhail Khodorkovsky, the question is not whether Mr Gudkov ran afoul of Russian law but rather why Russian law seems to matter so little to his peers who keep themselves in the Kremlin’s better graces." == Family == Gudkov is married and has two sons, [[Dmitry Gudkov|Dmitry]] and Vladimir. Dmitry is also a State Duma deputy (formerly also for the Just Russia party).[http://mobile.nytimes.com/2013/03/16/world/europe/russian-legislator-accused-of-treason-after-us-visit.html?referer= Russian Legislator Accused of Treason After U.S. Visit], [[The New York Times]] (15 March 2013) ==References== {{Reflist|33em}} ==External links== *[http://www.gudkov.ru/ Official website of Gennady Gudkov] {{ru icon}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Gudkov, Gennady}} [[Category:1956 births]] [[Category:A Just Russia politicians]] [[Category:21st-century Russian politicians]] [[Category:Communist Party of the Soviet Union members]] [[Category:KGB officers]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Members of the State Duma (Russian Federation)]] [[Category:People from Kolomna]] [[Category:Russian businesspeople]] [[Category:2011–2013 Russian protests]]

'''Ghanim Bin Saad Al Saad''' ({{lang-ar|غانم بن سعد ال سعد}} born 23 August 1964 in [[Doha]], [[Qatar]]) is a [[Qatari]] business leader and the Chairman of [[GSSG Holding]], a family business diversified into dozens of sectors and companies. He assumed a prominent role with other international leaders at the ‘Arab World Renewal’ forum in Paris in January 2015.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thinkers-doers.com/ |title=Thinkers & Doers: Leaders Who Make Things Happen |publisher=Thinkers & Doers |date=January 1, 2015}}</ref> He won the TAKREEM Award for Outstanding Corporate Leader in 2011.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Buly5WISK58 |title=Ghanim Bin Saad Al Saad - The TAKREEM Award for Outstanding Corporate Leader |publisher=Takreem Initiative |date=November 28, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.arabianbusiness.com/arabian-business-qatar-power-list-2012-443489.html?view=profile&itemid=443442#.VSfMTfmUecs |title=Arabian Business Qatar Power List 2012 |publisher=Arabian Business |date=January 1, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.takreem.net/IndividualDetails.aspx?Individual=2752&pageid=2744 |title=Ghanim Bin Saad Al Saad - Qatar |publisher=Takreem}}</ref> Al Saad ranks number 12 on the CEO Middle East Property Power List.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.arabianbusiness.com/ceo-property-power-list-269587.html?view=profile&itemid=269598#.VSfbiPmUect |title=CEO Middle East Property Power List |publisher=Arabian Business |date=April 22, 2010}}</ref> He was featured at number 27 on the Arabian Business Qatar Power List of 2012.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.arabianbusiness.com/arabian-business-qatar-power-list-2012-443489.html?view=profile&itemid=443442#.VSfMTfmUecs |title=Arabian Business Qatar Power List 2012 |publisher=Arabian Business |date=January 1, 2012}}</ref> Al Saad has also received the title of ‘Datuk’, the Malaysian equivalent of a British peerage from the King of Malaysia.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.kln.gov.my/web/qat_doha/home/-/asset_publisher/8pPT/blog/his-majesty-the-king-of-malaysia-honours-two-distinguished-qatari-citizens?redirect=%2Fweb%2Fqat_doha%2F |title=His Majesty the King of Malaysia Honours Two Distinguished Qatari Citizens |publisher=Official Website of the Embassy of Malaysia, Doha |access-date=May 4, 2015}}</ref> He also holds the position of chairman in several businesses including Al Imtiaz Investment Company, A'ayan Real Estate, Al Jazeera Academy, Rizon Partners, Jersey Group, Ghanim Bin Saad Al Saad & Sons Holdings Group, QatarAG and Rizon Jet. He is also the CEO and General Manager of First Finance Company, consultant and board member of Barwa Bank.
==Education== Al Saad received a BA in Social Sciences from Qatar University. He holds a master's degree in Social Policy & Administration from Kent University in the UK and a PhD from Greenwich University, London.<ref name=":0">{{cite web |url=http://www.takreem.net/IndividualDetails.aspx?Individual=2752&pageid=2744 |title=Ghanim Bin Saad Al Saad - Qatar |publisher=Takreem}}</ref>
== Career ==
Al Saad’s early career included the position of Director at the Ministry of Cabinet Affairs in 1998, after working at the Ministry of Justice and the Supreme Council for Planning in Qatar. He has held the position of Ambassador for Qatar’s Ministry of Foreign Affairs from 1998 to the present day.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.qatarinvcorp.com/about-us/board-of-director/ |title=About Ghanim Bin Saad Al Saad |publisher=Qatar Investment Corporation |access-date=May 4, 2015}}</ref> He has also worked as an adviser to the Prime Minister of Qatar, [[Hamad bin Jassim bin Jaber Al Thani|Sheikh Hamad Bin Jassim Al-Thani]], on business investments for Qatar’s Sovereign Fund, recommending a number of international acquisitions.<ref name=":0" />
He founded The Jersey Group in 1994, which is now known as the Ghanim Bin Saad Al Saad & Sons Holdings (GSSG) Group and which was incorporated it in 2007. GSSG includes over 30 companies around the world and spans real estate, manufacturing, contracting, engineering, information technology and telecommunications, aviation, automobiles, oil & gas, education, fitness, hospitality and fashion. The company’s corporate headquarters are in Qatar, with regional headquarters in London, Cairo and Singapore.
GSSG’s subsidiaries include Rizon Jet, the first private jet operator in the Middle East.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.arabaviation.com/en-us/countrybriefs/qatar/rizonjet.aspx |title=Country Briefs, Qatar |publisher=Arab Aviation |access-date=May 4, 2015}}</ref>
==Board memberships and charity==
Al Saad joined the General Assembly of Qatar Charity in 2001. He became a Board Member in 2001. He was appointed as Chairman of the charity on 13 October 2010 and he remains the current Chairman.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.unrwa.org/newsroom/press-releases/government-qatar-through-qatar-charity-contribute-us-10-million-unrwa |title=The Government of Qatar Through The Qatar Charity Contribute US $10 Million to UNRWA |publisher=United Nations |date=April 28, 2009}}</ref>
He held the position of Chairman and Managing Director of Barwa Real Estate Company (January 2006 – April 2011). Barwa Real estate is a semi-governmental real estate company 45% owned by Qatari Diar and 55% listed on the Doha Stock Exchange.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/people/person.asp?personId=159199229&ticker=TTA:TB&previousCapId=879846&previousTitle=IRPC%2520PCL |title=Industrials Sector, Marine Industry |publisher=Bloomberg Business |date=April 30, 2015}}</ref>
Al Saad was a Board Member, CEO and Managing Director of Qatari Diar Real Estate Company from 2008 to 2011. Qatari Diar is the wholly owned real estate arm of the Qatar Investment Authority and the Government of Qatar.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.euromoney.com/Article/1969071/Qatari-Diar-lays-foundations-for-global-growth.html |title=Qatari Diar Lays Foundations for Global Growth |publisher=EuroMoney |date=June 6, 2008}}</ref> He is currently the company's chief executive officer.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.arabianbusiness.com/companies/qatari-diar-real-estate-investment-company-69328.html|title=Qatari Diar Real Estate Investment Company|publisher=arabianbusiness.com|accessdate=22 July 2015}}</ref> He was Chairman of Barwa Bank from 2009 – 2010.
He held the position of Chairman of the Qatar Railways Company 2010 – 2011. Qatar Railways was set up under Al Saad’s chairmanship to drive the policy of having an integrated rail network inside Qatar and linking to the regional network of GCC (Gulf Co-operation Council) countries.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.qatarisbooming.com/article/qatari-diar-appoints-board-directors-qatar-railways-company |title=Qatari Diar Appoints Board of Directors for Qatar Railways Company |publisher=EuroMoney |date=March 6, 2011}}</ref>
Al Saad was a Member of the Qatar-Bahrain Causeway Committee.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2009/11/22/qatar-transport-railways-idUSGEE5AL03Z20091122 |title=Qatar eyes 2022 for key links in $23 bln rail deal |publisher=Reuters |date=November 22, 2009}}</ref> He has also been Chairman and Board Member of various subsidiaries and affiliates of Qatari Diar and Barwa Real Estate. Al Saad is a Board Member of the Qatar Investment Corporation.
=="Renewal of the Arab World" Summit in Paris, January 2015==
Al Saad was a featured speaker at the ‘Renewal of the Arab World’ conference at the Arab Institute in Paris, January 2015, along with President Francois Hollande of France, Foreign Minister of France Laurent Fabius and Jack Lang, President of the Arab Institute and many other international leaders dedicated to building stronger ties between all faiths.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thinkers-doers.com/wp-content/uploads/20150114-Programme-IMA-EN.pdf |title=International Program: Institute du Monde Arabe |publisher=Thinkers & Doers |date=January 14, 2015}}</ref>
== Awards and recognition== *TAKREEM Award for Outstanding Corporate Leader (2011)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.takreemawards.com/candidates/index.php?sect=2&i=21&year=2011 |title=TAKREEM official website |publisher=Takreemawards.com |date= |accessdate=2013-10-20}}</ref> *65th Rank in the ''[[Arabian Business|Arabian Business'<nowiki/>]]'' list "The world’s 100 most influential Arabs 2009"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.arabianbusiness.com/power-100-2009/list |title=Power 100 - Special Reports |publisher=[[Arabian Business]] |date= |accessdate=2013-10-20}}</ref> *50th on Arabian Business' "Qatar Power List 2015" <ref>{{Cite web|title = Qatar Power List 2015|url = http://www.arabianbusiness.com/qatar-power-list-2015-612180.html?view=profile&itemid=612179#.Vm_WpsmDFBc|website = Arabian Business|accessdate = 2015-12-15}}</ref>
